item.title: Milk Kanban
item.description: Original meaning of Kanban is that it’s a visual signal. We tend to think about Kanban in terms of boards, columns, index cards, etc. However, in principle, none of that is needed to design a Kanban system.

item.title: Harnessing AI in C# with Microsoft.Extensions.AI, Ollama, and MCP Server
item.description: In the previous post “Leveraging Microsoft.Extensions.AI for Tool Calling in C#“, we explored how to create custom tools that enhance the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs). We demonstrated
item.author: (Laurent Kempé)

item.title: Keepin' It Together - Dev Leader Weekly 87
item.description: Welcome to another issue of Dev Leader Weekly! In this issue, I discuss some thoughts as I'm working through a period of burnout.

item.title: REST Explained: Why the Web Runs on This Simple Idea - Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: If you've worked with web services, you've probably heard of REST. It's everywhere—from APIs powering your favorite apps to backend systems handling millions of users. But what exactly is REST, and why is it the go-to approach for modern web development? Let’s break it down.

item.title: C# Flags: Beginner's Guide
item.description:
In this session, we dive into Flags in C#—a powerful feature that allows software engineers to represent multiple options within a single data field. You'll learn how to efficiently manage combinations of boolean values using bitwise operations.
🚀 What You'll Learn: ✅ What Flags are and why they matter ✅ How to define and use a Flags Enum ✅ Adding, removing, and checking flags with bitwise operations ✅ Real-world examples and best practices
💡 Perfect for beginners and experienced C# developers looking to level up their enum game!
Here's some useful links: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/fundamentals/runtime-libraries/system-flagsattribute
item.author: (Hassan Habib)

item.title: An introduction to Magit, an Emacs mode for Git
item.description: Learn how to use Magit, an essential tool for any git-loving Emacs user. Magit supercharges your git workflow by removing the tedium of writing arcane commands and replacing them with a simple and ergonomic user interface.

item.title: FREE FOR ALL! - Engineering Manager AMA
item.description:
I am completely burnt out and figured we'd just have an open discussion about whatever is on your mind. Until the chat picks up, I'll just blab about stuff that is still giving me energy. Come hang out!
As with all livestreams, I'm looking forward to answering YOUR questions! So join me live and ask in the chat, or you can comment now and I can try to get it answered while I stream.

item.title: Six mistakes I made and one I avoided
item.description: I'm still working on my point-and-click puzzle game made from dioramas.

item.title: Transformers without Normalization - DynamicTanh
The COST of double-entry accounting
item.description: Sometimes I think the most important paper of our times is Scalability! But at what COST? We build “web-scale” systems and get excited about how scalable they are and how we solve the problems of scale, but we do not measure the COST: Configuration that Outperforms a Single Thread. We lack reasonable, well-done single-threaded implementations for different domains. One of which is ledger and accounting.

item.title: Finding the opposite of what you have with rails invert_where
item.description: Need to fetch the opposite data for an existing ActiveRecord query? Rails invert_where makes it effortless, but be careful with the side effects.

item.title: The Photographer Who Takes No Pictures
item.description: How a trip in 2012 transformed my relationship with photography—from staged performances to capturing genuine moments that matter, for engagement rather than validation.

item.title: Sneaky Bits: Advanced Data Smuggling Techniques (ASCII Smuggler Updates) · Embrace The Red
item.description: This post highlights some new research, tricks and improvements on data smuggling techniques.

item.title: Scrum Fatigue: Why It Happens and How to Fix It
item.description: Scrum is widely used to boost collaboration and speed up software delivery. But for many teams, it leads to stress and burnout. Why does Scrum sometimes feel exhausting? More importantly, how can we fix it?

item.title: Carefully But Purposefully Oxidising Ubuntu
item.description: This post explores modern equivalents of foundational system utilities such as coreutils and sudo, introduces an experimental utility for testing them, and maps out a path to their widespread adoption in Ubuntu.

item.title: Elixir Makes You Make Good Decisions
item.description: How choosing Elixir made building screen.garden faster and more correct.

item.title: Should we replace Spark with DuckDB?
item.description: I was attending a DuckDB meetup in Leuven, where a presenter was detailing how they replaced Spark with DuckDB to cut costs, when rather abruptly, someone in the audience asked, “How do I know if I should really use DuckDB now, me being not a data engineer? What if my query is heavier than expected? What if my data fluctuates and just sometimes goes beyond a single machine?”. The presenter admitted that you set up the architecture once, do your best benchmarking, and hope for the data dynamics to stay the same.

item.title: My Thoughts on the Future of "AI"
item.description: I have very wide error bars on the potential future of large language models, and I think you should too. It's possible LLMs basically lead to AGI, and it's also possible they platteau.
